Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Passive Acoustic Monitoring in long-term oceanographic observations of the Bering Strait
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funds are provided to establish a base program for year-round acoustic monitoring of marine mammals in Bering Strait. Instrumentation will be added onto an existing high resolution physical and biological mooring program (National Science Foundation-Arctic Observing Network (AON) and RUSsian American Long-term Census of the Arctic), also supported by annual survey data. The combination of these data sets will provide urgently required, base-line information on how species presence varies seasonally with changes in sea ice, currents, ocean water temperatures and freshwater flow. Building on opportunistic proof-of-concept deployments in the strait in the last 2 years, the proposed effort will also provide critical, consistent data on interannual variability, and allow for the testing of cutting edge scientific hypotheses such as: how do oceanographic conditions dictate the residency of different marine mammal species? Are temperate species ?invading? the Arctic? What is the correlation between ice cover and marine mammal sound production?

The Bering Strait is the only oceanic connection between the Pacific and the Arctic oceans. It is through this narrow (~85 km) passageway that the entire population of Bering-Chukchi-Beaufort bowhead whales passes twice yearly and that herds of beluga whales access Arctic waters. It is thought to be year-round habitat for ice seals and walrus . The Bering Strait is also the path by which Pacific sub-Arctic marine species are invading the Arctic. As the Northwest Passage becomes a viable Pacific-Atlantic shipping route, every ship along this route will pass through Bering Strait. It is, therefore, the region where climate change and changing anthropogenic utilization may have sizeable impacts on local marine fauna, and where changing fluxes of marine mammals to the Arctic can be well observed. Passive acoustic monitoring is the only method currently available to identify year-round, and in all weather conditions, the presence of marine mammals and other physical (ice movement) or anthropogenic (ships, oil and gas seismic exploration) sounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved the deployment of underwater recorders (hydrophones) on three oceanographic moorings in the Bering Strait. This project was part of the Arctic Observing Network (AON) which involves providing observational Arctic data to the broader scientific community. In this instance, once downloaded, the data collected could be used to: 1) Document the inter-seasonal and inter-annual presence of vocal marine mammals (Arctic and sub-Arctic) in the Bering Strait; 2) Integrate these detections with co-located physical oceanographic data to better understand how the physical environment influences the biological inhabitants of that environment; 3) Document ambient noise levels in the Bering Strait to asses the impact of commercial shipping on noise levels; and 4) Report to local communities on the health of the Bering Strait ecosystem including  information on new species,  and residency times of vocal Arctic species. 

The Intellectual Merit achievements of this project are:

Hydrophone packages were deployed with NSF support starting in July 2012 and continuing until July 2015. The data acquired, and metadata associated, have been uploaded and are freely available at http://arctidata.io as required by AON. To date, these data have been, and are being used, for a M.S. degree, two PhD degrees and a post-doctoral position at the University of Washington. Additionally, the data have been shared with the WIldlife Conservation Society and JASCO ltd. and are being used in a synthesis of data collected by the Distributed Biological Observatory project that has established biological "hot spots" in the Pacific Arctic. To date, four peer-reviewed publications have resulted from these data with three more in preparation. 

The Broader Impacts achievements of this project include:

The project, and data from the project, have been presented to the general public at the World Science Festival, New York, NY (2013), during Polar Science Weekend, Seattle WA (2013-15) and during  “Strait Science Series" talks at the University of Alaska Norhtwest campus (2014, 2015). Numerous radio and press interviews regarding shipping and animal presence in Bering Strait resulted from an Ocean Sciences 2014 presentation. The results were shared as part of an invited talk for the American Cetacean Society's Symposium: "Our Changing Oceans." A Pew Arctic “science short” on noise and the Arctic was produced and distributed online and to local communities (http://www.pewenvironment.org/news-room/fact-sheets/science-short-arctic-noise-85899480843). The project was also featured on NSF's Science360.gov "Weather or Not!"  on World Ocean's Day 2016 (https://science360.gov/radio/episode/ed980c1b-6ab0-47f9-9d41-f49bdfe30583/world-oceans-day-better-time-eavesdrop-sounds-deep-turns-out).
